front.title: Evidence Status and Revocation Protocol for Proof of Process

abstract.t: This document defines the evidence status and revocation protocol for the Proof of Process architecture. It specifies mechanisms for revoking compromised evidence chains, checking the validity status of previously issued attestation results, and revoking device attestation certificates when Attester keys are compromised. The protocol balances the need for timely revocation with author privacy by using privacy- preserving status checking that does not reveal which specific evidence chains are being queried.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Proof of Process architecture generates long-lived evidence chains and attestation results that Relying Parties may depend on months or years after their creation. Over such time spans, the security assumptions underlying the evidence may change: device keys may be compromised, software vulnerabilities may be discovered in Attester implementations, or authors may discover that evidence was collected during periods of unauthorized access to their devices.

This document defines a revocation and status checking protocol that allows evidence chains and device certificates to be revoked, and that allows Relying Parties to check the current validity of evidence they depend on. The protocol draws on established revocation mechanisms from the PKI ecosystem (, ) while adapting them to the specific requirements of the Proof of Process architecture.

The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Evidence Revocation
section.t: An author MAY revoke a specific evidence chain or a range of evidence records within a chain. Revocation is performed by submitting a signed revocation request to the status service. The revocation request MUST be signed with the same device key that produced the original evidence, or with a designated revocation key established during enrollment.

The revocation request contains the evidence chain identifier, the range of sequence numbers to revoke (or a wildcard indicating the entire chain), a revocation reason code, and an optional revocation timestamp. Valid reason codes include key compromise, software vulnerability, unauthorized access, and voluntary withdrawal. The request is encoded in CBOR () and wrapped in a COSE_Sign1 structure ().

Once a revocation request is accepted, the status service MUST include the revoked evidence in all subsequent status responses. Revocation is permanent and cannot be reversed. If an author wishes to re-establish evidence for a work whose chain was revoked, they MUST create a new evidence chain from the current document state.

section.title: Status Checking Protocol
section.t: Relying Parties check the validity of evidence chains and device certificates using a status checking protocol inspired by OCSP (). The Relying Party sends a status request containing the hash of the evidence chain identifier to the status service. The service responds with a signed status response indicating whether the evidence is valid, revoked, or unknown.

To protect author privacy, the status checking protocol uses a blinded query mechanism. The Relying Party computes a blinded hash of the evidence chain identifier and sends this blinded value to the status service. The service evaluates the query against its revocation database without learning which specific evidence chain is being checked. This prevents the status service from building a profile of which evidence chains are most frequently queried.

Status responses are signed by the status service key and include a freshness timestamp and a next-update time. Relying Parties SHOULD cache status responses until the next-update time to reduce query frequency. A cached response that has passed its next-update time MUST be refreshed before the Relying Party makes any new trust decisions based on the corresponding evidence.

section.title: Device Certificate Revocation
section.t: Device attestation certificates issued during enrollment may need to be revoked if the Attester's private key is compromised. Certificate revocation follows the standard X.509 revocation model (), with the Endorser publishing Certificate Revocation Lists (CRLs) at regular intervals. Verifiers MUST check the revocation status of the device certificate before accepting evidence signed by the corresponding key as described in the RATS architecture ().

When a device certificate is revoked, all evidence produced by that device after the revocation effective date is automatically considered invalid. Evidence produced before the revocation effective date remains valid unless separately revoked through the evidence revocation mechanism described above. This distinction allows Relying Parties to continue trusting historical evidence from a device whose key was compromised at a known point in time.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The revocation protocol introduces a dependency on the availability of the status service. If the status service is unreachable, Relying Parties must decide whether to accept evidence without a fresh status check (fail-open) or reject it (fail-closed). This document RECOMMENDS a fail-closed policy for high-value evidence, such as evidence used in legal proceedings, and permits fail-open with cached responses for lower-stakes applications.
